ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of the basic techniques of glassblowing, many of which are useful in a research-lab setting. For example, I learned what the numbers for different ground-glass joints actually signify and how to score and break glass safely. I also learned how to make side-seals, straight-seals, bends, tapers, Vigreux columns, and bulbs. I learned how to use a wet saw to cut glass and I gained an appreciation for glassblowing and the work our glassblowers do on a daily basis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The biggest factor limiting me from learning the techniques taught in this course was the time required to practice the skills. For safety reasons, we were only allowed to work in the shop when the shop was open. These hours largely conflict with hours graduate students need to be working in lab. I understand that the logistics would be difficult, but it would be nice to have evening or weekend hours available for students to work.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Taking this class is an opportunity unique to Yale and I would encourage everyone to take advantage of it.
